NEWS-LETTER

McCoy College Concerned
By Acute Parking Problem
Dr. R. A. Mumma, Dean of McCoy College, this week expressed
his concern over the increasingly
critical parking situation at Hopkins, stating, "Ultimately the
parking problem will affects our
evening school enrollment."

sistant plant manager announced.
George Creel, student member
of the parking commission, said
there had been several suggestions offered for a clearing up of
the problem, but so far none
have been practicable. He emphasized that students are allowed
to park only where there are
white lines on the curb, and that
faculty parking is allowed where
there are yellow lines. "There
are about six students who consistently violate the parking regulations. They will get letters in
the near future, and their names
will go to Dean Shaffer for further action."
There is a movement underway
to restrict faculty parking to faculty parking lots only.

The dean said that although he
had no authority over the flow
of traffic and parking on the campus, he was very much concerned,
since he had received many complaints from the students of McCoy College.
The situation, which was made
even more critical this year by
the banning of parking on Charles
Street and San Martin Drive.

areas. Coupled with this is the fact
that McCoy College has the largest
enrollment in its history this year,

CORRECTION
Last week in these columns, in
Leslie Norins' letter, titled "Campus
Delusion," a quote by Daniel Gilman
was inadvertently 'printed as, "Universities easily fall into ruts. Almost
every speech requires a fresh start."
The quote should have read, "Universities easily falli nto the ruts. Almost
every epoch requires a fresh start."
The News-Letter. regrets the error.
—Ed.
FROM DEAR OLD ED .
Gentlemen:
Congratulations on your excellent editorial of Oct. 22, on the
problem of fraternity discrimination
With one point of your
article I would take issue—your
criticism of "those of a crusading
and fanatical bent who clamor for
immediate and full integration."
Any• man who feels so strongly
about prejudice that he is willing
to risk disrupting the intimacy
of brotherly circles to try to end
it is deservini of the highest
praise. Unfortunately, I cannot
lay claim to such "extremism"
myself.

A much smaller group, mostly freshmen, without the aid
'of beer and a flapping Blue Jay, also demonstrated Hopkins
spirit the same night. During the course of a mixer to which
Hopkins men were sent a blanket invitation, one of our students,
was asked to leave, not by any of the girls at the affair, but
by the director of the institution, and not because of any misconduct on the boy's part, but because of his color. The boy left.
Word of the situation had gotten about to the other Hopkins
men there and, in protest, about twenty others left also.
Unfortunately, but quite understandably, this demonstration of spirit—true Hopkins spirit, we feel—was marred by
some amount of' undue emotionalism. Several of the boys then
and there wrote what has been described as a "strong" letter
to the director. There was also some talk of "forcing" the institution to change its policy.
It has often been remarked that racial and religious discrimination would disappear if left to young people themselves.
This view is corroborated by such evidence as a nationwide
Roper.survey of college students in 1950 which revealed that
60% of the students opposed any discrimination while only 20%
favored exclusion. An additional 20% believed proportional
limitation to be the solution. However,.young people are often
the part of a system which prevents them from exercising
the right of free association. In the case of the girls at Friday's
affair, for example, there was the director (who, incidentally,
said he was merely following policy set not by him, but by his
institution's Board of Control.)
Because of the letter \written by our boys in the heat of the
moment, the girls at the institution claim that their own atteMpts
at changing policy will be hampered.

CORRECTION
Last week in these columns, in
Leslie Norins' letter, titled "Campus
Delusion," a quote by Daniel Gilman
was inadvertently 'printed as, "Universities easily fall into ruts. Almost
every speech requires a fresh start."
The quote should have read, "Universities easily falli nto the ruts. Almost
every epoch requires a fresh start."
The News-Letter. regrets the error.
—Ed.

A much smaller group, mostly freshmen, without the aid
'of beer and a flapping Blue Jay, also demonstrated Hopkins
spirit the same night. During the course of a mixer to which
Hopkins men were sent a blanket invitation, one of our students,
was asked to leave, not by any of the girls at the affair, but
by the director of the institution, and not because of any misconduct on the boy's part, but because of his color. The boy left.
Word of the situation had gotten about to the other Hopkins
men there and, in protest, about twenty others left also.
Unfortunately, but quite understandably, this demonstration of spirit—true Hopkins spirit, we feel—was marred by
some amount of' undue emotionalism. Several of the boys then
and there wrote what has been described as a "strong" letter
to the director. There was also some talk of "forcing" the institution to change its policy.
It has often been remarked that racial and religious discrimination would disappear if left to young people themselves.
This view is corroborated by such evidence as a nationwide
Roper.survey of college students in 1950 which revealed that
60% of the students opposed any discrimination while only 20%
favored exclusion. An additional 20% believed proportional
limitation to be the solution. However,.young people are often
the part of a system which prevents them from exercising
the right of free association. In the case of the girls at Friday's
affair, for example, there was the director (who, incidentally,
said he was merely following policy set not by him, but by his
institution's Board of Control.)
Because of the letter \written by our boys in the heat of the
moment, the girls at the institution claim that their own atteMpts
at changing policy will be hampered.

EDWARD HIRSCHMANN
Mr. Hirschmann (History, '54) is
